homepage.topHeader: Every Bitcoin private key and address is on this website.
homepage.topSubheader: Satoshi Nakamoto's private key is hidden on one of the pages...
homepage.searchBarSubheader: If you are curious which page your private key is on, you can search for it.
homepage.searchBarSuggestion: Although, is entering your own private key on a random website really a good idea?
homepage.searchBarErrMsg: That's not a valid private key!
homepage.ominousMsgLink: Ominous message hidden in the private keys

keyspage.title: {version} keys page {page} of {maxPage}
keyspage.testnetWarning: You are currently exploring testnet keys. Testnet is an alternative Bitcoin blockchain that developers use for testing. Testnet coins do not hold any value.

about.title: About ElliptiKeys
about.mainDescription: As you could probably tell, this site is based off the ever-popular keys.lol site. However, this version is capable of deriving every public key type including SegWit and Bech32 addresses, as opposed to only Legacy-type addresses. This version also displays all compressed private keys alongside uncompressed ones.
about.toVisualize: To visualize how many private keys there really are and how you will never actually find any coins on here, I recommend watching this video.
about.howItWorks: Knowing how massive the possible keyspace truly is, storing every single private and public key simply would not be possible. The keys are all dynamically computed when the page is loaded.
about.howItWorks2: Since we know a private key is simply a number somewhere between 1 and 2^256, it calculates them starting at n=([page number] * [keys/page]) and derives every private key and its corresponding address formats from n to n + [keys/page]. Once the private and public keys have been derived, it uses the Blockchain.com API to perform the balance checking.
about.redKeys: • Keys that have never been used will turn red.
about.yellowKeys: • Keys that have been previously used that currently have zero balance will turn yellow.
about.greenKeys: • Keys that currently contain coins will turn green.
about.cyanKeys: • If you search for a private key, its text on the page will turn cyan.
about.knowMore: If you would like to know more about how this happens behind the scenes, I recommend taking a look at this article.
about.btcBalanceChecker: Bitcoin balance checker powered by Blockchain.com Data API and Haskoin API for Testnet
about.priceTickerData: Price ticker data pulled from CoinGecko
about.icons8: Icons sourced from Icons8
about.angular: Coded with Angular framework
about.cryptoJs: JS cryptographic hashing library from CryptoJS
about.ellipticCurve: Elliptic Curve implementation by paulmillr

donate.title: Donate | ElliptiKeys
donate.mainDescription: ElliptiKeys is a project made to educate people about the security of the Bitcoin network. Many people are concerned that their private key will be brute-forced, and this site is meant to show that this will simply never be the case.
donate.openSource: All of the code for the site is 100% open-source and can be compiled and ran on any computer :)
donate.wishToSupport: If you wish to support this site, any donation is greatly appreciated!

index.title: ElliptiKeys Blockchain Explorer
index.poweredBy: Powered by Blockchain.com and Haskoin
index.mainDescription: Using this tool, you can look up any Bitcoin or Testnet block number, address, transaction, or even a private key (please not your own) to view its data.

walletGenerator.scamWarning: TESTNET SCAM WARNING: TESTNET COINS HAVE NO VALUE!

index.title: ElliptiKeys Wallet Generator
index.alertText: !!! WARNING: You appear to be connected to the Internet. If you wish to generate important wallets, it is recommended to download the ElliptiKeys source code and run it offline to minimize risk of your wallet being compromised.

tooFar.title: Too far!
tooFar.topSubheader: There aren't THAT many keys, silly!
